text: stars, what makes the oceans the weather.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're born scientists.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then something happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When we hit the danger years, the danger years of junior high school and high school, that's when it's literally crushed out of us.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Those are the worst.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Every little flower of curiosity, said Einstein, is crushed by society itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because we have to learn all these facts, figures, memorization, we think that memorization is science.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's not true at all.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My daughter had to take the Regents exam once, and she had to memorize all these facts and figures about minerals, crystals for a geology exam.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Nowhere did I see the true driving force of geology, which is continental drift.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's the organizing principle for all of geology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And yet the exam was memorizing all the names of the crystals and the minerals.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then later she comes up to me and says, Daddy, why would anyone want to become a scientist?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That was the most humiliating event in my entire life.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I felt like taking that book and ripping it apart, because that exam was crushing, crushing curiosity right out of the next generation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then we wonder, hey, how come people are not more interested in science?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Duh, okay?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Also take a look at how Richard Feynman looked at this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Richard Feynman, the Nobel Laureate, was a child, and his father would take him to the forest.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and explain why birds are shy.
